moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6:
The Queens gambit Declined with 2.e6  is much more common than the Queen's 
  Gambit Accepted ( 2.dxc4) and the Slav ( 2.c6).l
moves.3. Nc3: Putting pressure on the d5 pawn and at the same time developing a piece.
moves.3... Nf6: Black also develops a piece and supports the d5 pawn
moves.4. Nf3: Developing a piece and also supporting the d4 pawn
moves.5. Bg5:
Seeming fairly logical by developing pieces to there most aggressive squares
 but ideally with an eye on the center.
moves.5... Nbd7:
In any case of a future Bxf6 then Black can recapture with the knight and White
 would not get a good exchange by doing so.
moves.6. e3:
Allows the light squared bishop to see light of day and at the same time the 
 f1 bishop supports the c4 pawn.
moves.6... O-O: Black gets his King to safety and allows his Rook to come into the game.
moves.7. Rc1 c6: Supporting the d5 pawn and also allowing the Queen access to the Queen side.
moves.8. Bd3:
White prepares to now castle King side and also he puts his bishop on a very 
 good diagonal that leads towards Black's King.
moves.8... dxc4:
Black gives up his center to in exchange 1. Allow his f6 knight to hop to d5 next 
 move and 2. To get the Bishop of the b1-h7 diagonal for a bit.
moves.9. Bxc4 Nd5:
Black's 9th move was introduced by Jose Raul Capablanca as a maneuver to 
 free up some space in the Queen's Gambit Declined. Black is following the 
 strategic principle that the side with the least amount of territory should
 exchange some pieces to relieve the annoying cramp.
moves.10. Bxe7: I think that  was pretty much forced.
moves.11. Ne4:
This is Alexander Alekhine's invention. The rather mature Alexander Alekhine is
 very happy to go straight into 11. Qb4   12. Qd2  Qxd2  13. Kxd2, which leads
 to a slightly superior endgame for White.
moves.12. Ng3:
Swapping is really not a very good idea because all Black does is he recaptures
 with the knight and that also allows the Bishop to come to d7, gives Black some
 more space and completing his development and connecting the rooks.
moves.12... e5:
Black is doing this for the sake of gaining some more space and being less and
 less cramped but it allows the White knight to come to f5 where it may cause
 some problems for Black.
moves.13. O-O:
White gets his King to safety bring his rook into the game and can possibly play
 a future Re1 and put the Rook on the same file as the Black Queen, which can
 be fairly dangerous for Black- Big time!
moves.13... exd4 14. Nf5:
White kinda makes an in-between move at this point. But still a better move
 might possibly be 14. exd4 and then followed by 15. Re1, when White 
 introduces his Rook with a tempo. But in the long run I think that black will be
 able to gain equality.
moves.15... Ne5:
Black is threatening the c4 bishop with his knight and also it allows his c8 
 bishop to see daylight.
moves.16. Bb3: A swap off is not good for White so he retreats his bishop.
moves.16... Bxf5:
Black knows that his Bishop would hardly be any use so he swaps it off for the 
  fairly aggressive knight.
moves.17. Nxf5: White recaptures and still has a fairly aggressive knight.
moves.17... Qb6:
?   Now this is the move that set up Black's future problems. The fairly forced       17.g6 would chase the f5 knight  away from its fairly aggressive position and also would equalize the game. The position one or two moves ago seemed to
  be quite simple, but now Alekhine takes the initiative end of things and
 creating threat after threat, never lets up.
moves.18. Qd6: ! Threatening the e5 knight and also going down Black's throat in a way.
moves.19. Rfd1: White gets his other Rook doing something....
moves.19... Rad8:
Black puts his Rook on the same file as White's Queen meaning that White
   must now retreat his Queen
moves.20. Qg3: The Queen retreats and Is also threatening 21. Qxg7 checkmate!
moves.20... g6:
A forced move If  20.Ne8  21. Nh6   Kh8  22. Nxf7  will win White some 
  material.
moves.21. Qg5: !  White is now threatening 22. Rd6  which hits Black's Knight.
moves.21... Kh8:
Black gets his King of the g- file so he can simply threaten to wipe out White's 
 Knight  with 22.pxf5
moves.22. Nd6: And now  23. Nxf7   threatens to eat some material.
moves.22... Kg7:
To give the  f7 pawn more support, but it is not ideal for his King he has walked 
 back on the g-file where he is pinned again
moves.23. e4:
!   Even the e-pawn joins in the attack. This move also frees the 3rd rank for 
      White's Rooks to come to the Kingside.
moves.23... Ng8: So Black can play 24. f6 and hopes to stay alive.
moves.24. Rd3: !   White is correct to bring in his reinforcements to get at the Black King.
moves.24... f6:
As you can now see a rather sweet pattern would  result from 24. h6 25. Nf5 
 Kh7  26. Nxh6!  f6   27. Nf5!  fxg5  28. Rh3  with checkmate to follow!
moves.26. Qxg6:
Black resigns here. Lasker laid down his King because he had no desire to
  suffer through  26. hxg6   27. Rh3   Nh6  28. Rxh6 Checkmate. A very very
  devastating victory for Alexander Alekhine.
